key_points: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer announced the impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump will start the week of Feb. 8.
The House will deliver the impeachment article against Trump to the Senate on Monday, formally starting trial proceedings.
The announcement follows a request from Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell to delay the trial to allow Trump's legal team time to prepare.
Senate members will be sworn in as jurors on Tuesday, ahead of the trial's commencement.
Doug Andres, McConnell's spokesman, expressed satisfaction with the delay, highlighting the importance of due process and fairness.
This trial marks the first time a former president will face impeachment proceedings.
Some Senate Republicans argue the trial is unconstitutional because Trump is no longer in office.
A Senate debate and vote on the trial's validity are anticipated in the coming weeks.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi emphasized the fairness of the process and noted Trump's legal team will have had ample time to prepare.
Pelosi's letter to the House Democratic caucus insists on the readiness of their Managers for the trial.
